text: what's up outliers today we're going to talk about making a backdoor Roth IRA contribution so you could trade options in your IRA account so let's talk first about why a Roth versus a traditional then we'll talk about why back door and I'm going to give you literally a step-by-step process I literally just completed mine for the year so sharing with you for years so the first thing why a Roth well a Roth allows for tax fre growth of your Capital very similar to a traditional in that sense however as compared to traditional where there's no tax on the contribution with a WTH You tax on the contribution but then you are not a on the withdrawal this is useful if you think your income in the future is likely to be higher than it is now and for a lot of traders that will be the case for people that are working in W2 jobs and stuff like that probably less so obviously consult a tax professional not a dude on the internet Next Step why back door well it's actually pretty simple it's because if you fall into some of these various buckets you literally cannot contribute to a Roth IRA so for example if you're single and you make over 161,000 you cannot contribute if you're married filed jointly you cannot contribute if it's over 240,000 which is kind of a bummer because again for Traders and people who invest there's a good

literally cannot contribute to a Roth IRA so for example if you're single and you make over 161,000 you cannot contribute if you're married filed jointly you cannot contribute if it's over 240,000 which is kind of a bummer because again for Traders and people who invest there's a good chance you're going to be worth more in the future than you are today so this is why we use the backd door contribution is because it is a legal method for high income earners to contribute to a Roth account so now let's talk about the steps to complete it's actually really easy so the first thing is you're going to make a non-deductible contribution to a traditional IRA why is it not deductible well it's for the same reasons that you kind of see over here if you have a certain amount of income in this case if you're single and you make over 89k you can no longer take the deduction on a traditional contribution so the majority of instances this is what's going to be the case for people that are doing a backdoor contribution so you're going to start with a non-deductible contribution which we'll talk about how to track that a little bit later it's again very simple there's essentially two forms that you need and that's it step two is an optional holding period I essentially don't really use this this is some people do it out of a bit of concern trying

talk about how to track that a little bit later it's again very simple there's essentially two forms that you need and that's it step two is an optional holding period I essentially don't really use this this is some people do it out of a bit of concern trying to reduce their potential footprint for being flagged but the reality is it's completely illegal to do and and if you acrew any gains while you hold that position then you run into the prata rule so once you have your traditional you make your contribution that's non-deductible then you once your funds settle which typically takes a couple days by itself we convert it to a WTH Ira if there are no gains on the traditional then there's no tax on the conversion if there is or are gains existing or you acre them in the meantime before you complete the conversion then you do pay taxes on the gains but there is no penalty to do so so it's essentially just going to increase your tax footprint a little bit unnecessarily now the last thing we report the conversion on our taxes and there's essentially two forms there's the IRS form 8606 which is for UND deductible contributions you literally can just type in IRS form 8606 and it'll pop up and then your broker will send you a form 199 R which is a conversion notice essentially a new distributions from retirement accounts that one comes from

the IRS form 8606 which is for UND deductible contributions you literally can just type in IRS form 8606 and it'll pop up and then your broker will send you a form 199 R which is a conversion notice essentially a new distributions from retirement accounts that one comes from your broker now I do not do my own taxes I have them for a long time I have a tax professional that helps me with all this stuff but what you'll notice is even if you don't do your taxes yourself it's useful to know these documents to know the process so that you're aware so for those that are on Schwab that's who I use essentially what you're going to do is initiate a transfer and you can see when you start the transfer you're going to say that I want to cash whatever you have in there and then down here below my head one second let me slide me out of the way then down further below this there will be essentially a from account to account and when you click that it's going to detect that it is Ira or retirement accounts so this will pop up at the top so then all you do is click this here that says to complete the Roth conversion you click that and then this form pops up and then essentially you say I want to take it from the traditional I want to put it into the

pop up at the top so then all you do is click this here that says to complete the Roth conversion you click that and then this form pops up and then essentially you say I want to take it from the traditional I want to put it into the Roth I want to do a there's two different there's b or complete and then a partial so typically would be complete cuz you want to get everything out of the account and then move it into to the Roth and then once you complete that that's when you get your form 8606 to be able to file that and that's when you also wait until your broker gives you your 1099 R so the whole point behind doing this is to be able to move money into your Roth IRA once you get priced out of being able to directly contribute and this isn't specific for options trading I do trade options in my IRA accounts ever this is for anybody that's trying to get money into your Roth IRA this process is about the same so if there's any questions on how this works let me know be an outlier I'll see you later
